results.abstract: US astronaut David Wolf returns to Earth aboard space shuttle Endeavour after four months aboard Mir space station (M)

headline.main: Mir Astronaut Returns to Earth, With Family and Pizza on Hand

results.snippet: An ecstatic David Wolf returned to Earth aboard the space shuttle Endeavour today after four long, lonely months on the Russian space station Mir.    The shuttle and its crew of seven swooped through a vividly clear sky just before sunset and landed...
results.lead_paragraph: An ecstatic David Wolf returned to Earth aboard the space shuttle Endeavour today after four long, lonely months on the Russian space station Mir. The shuttle and its crew of seven swooped through a vividly clear sky just before sunset and landed on the concrete runway, right on time.

results.abstract: Article on bobsledding events at upcoming Nagano Games; photo (M)
results.snippet: OLYMPIC bobsledding is about as harrowing as skydiving before the parachute opens or gunning an unlimited hydroplane at 125 miles an hour when an unexpected wave turns up.    The Nagano bobsled course measures 1,380 meters, almost seven-eighths of a...
results.lead_paragraph: OLYMPIC bobsledding is about as harrowing as skydiving before the parachute opens or gunning an unlimited hydroplane at 125 miles an hour when an unexpected wave turns up. The Nagano bobsled course measures 1,380 meters, almost seven-eighths of a mile, and has 15 curves. The sleds and riders shoot down a twisting, refrigerated run through hairpin turns, S curves and labyrinths. They endure G forces of five times those of gravity, or twice as much as the G forces on an astronaut during a shuttle launch. At times, the bobsledders exceed 80 m.p.h.

results.abstract: Article on expert or celebrity cruise speaker; drawing (L)
results.snippet: EVERY ocean cruise comes wrapped in the myth that the harried traveler finally gets away from it all. No telephones, no traffic, no nothing -- just lots of time and an endless expanse of sparkling water. It offers leisure in the most concentrated...
results.lead_paragraph: EVERY ocean cruise comes wrapped in the myth that the harried traveler finally gets away from it all. No telephones, no traffic, no nothing -- just lots of time and an endless expanse of sparkling water. It offers leisure in the most concentrated form to be found outside a flotation tank. The cruise lines know better. Doing nothing is highly stressful, which is why many of them have entertainment divisions working day and night to insure that passengers never have to confront an idle moment. In the process, a fabulous occupational category has emerged: the cruise speaker.

headline.main: January 25-31; Who Needs to Talk? If the Suit Fits, He Stays.

results.snippet: First, the Russians complained that Dr. Andrew S. W. Thomas, the American astronaut, was a malcontent for saying his emergency spacesuit was too small. Then, they complained that his Russian wasn't good enough.
results.lead_paragraph: First, the Russians complained that Dr. Andrew S. W. Thomas, the American astronaut, was a malcontent for saying his emergency spacesuit was too small. Then, they complained that his Russian wasn't good enough.

results.abstract: Dr David A Wolf, US space shuttle astronaut, says he is still wobbly and that his body still feels as if it is spinning, day after returning to Earth following four months aboard orbiting Mir space station (S)

headline.main: Astronaut Says He's Still Wobbly After Months of Weightlessness

results.snippet: Pale and thinner after four months on the Mir space station, Dr. David A. Wolf, the United States astronaut, said today that he was still wobbly and that his body sometimes felt as though it was spinning.    ''To be honest, I'm hurting a bit,'' he...
results.lead_paragraph: Pale and thinner after four months on the Mir space station, Dr. David A. Wolf, the United States astronaut, said today that he was still wobbly and that his body sometimes felt as though it was spinning. ''To be honest, I'm hurting a bit,'' he said. ''When I tilt my head, the world goes upside-down.''

results.abstract: Private experts score as reckless NASA decision to include Senator John Glenn and schoolteacher Barbara Morgan as space shuttle astronauts and seek even more diversity; cite innate dangers posed by shuttle; even NASA's top safety experts say agency's public assertions of improved safety are exaggerated; graph (L)

headline.main: Experts Fault NASA for Boasting of Safer Shuttle

results.snippet: Citing a safer space shuttle, NASA is widening the astronaut ranks to include a senator and a schoolteacher, and hopes for even more diversity. But private experts criticize the change as reckless, given the innate dangers posed by the winged...
results.lead_paragraph: Citing a safer space shuttle, NASA is widening the astronaut ranks to include a senator and a schoolteacher, and hopes for even more diversity. But private experts criticize the change as reckless, given the innate dangers posed by the winged spaceships. And even NASA's top safety experts say the agency's public assertions of improved safety are exaggerated. Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration acknowledge that space travel is dangerous, but they tend to play down the charges and internal disputes, saying that new shuttle crew members will face no undue risks and that, in any case, they will be fully informed of the hazards.

results.abstract: Two veteran astronauts who are also doctors, Chiaki Mukai and Scott Parazynski, are scheduled to accompany Sen John Glenn, NASA's oldest astronaut, into space in October (S)

headline.main: National News Briefs; Glenn's Space Flight Will Include 2 Doctors

results.snippet: Two doctors are scheduled to accompany Senator John Glenn, NASA's oldest astronaut, into space in October.    One is a heart surgeon. The other is trained in emergency medicine.
results.lead_paragraph: Two doctors are scheduled to accompany Senator John Glenn, NASA's oldest astronaut, into space in October. One is a heart surgeon. The other is trained in emergency medicine.

results.abstract: Plans for space tourism, for less expensive satellite launchings and for same-day global package deliveries are fueling surge in private research on reusable space vehicles; X Prize Foundation is offering $10 million to first private team that successfully sends spaceship with three adults on board to 62 miles above Earth and back two times in two weeks; 12 American teams and four foreign have registered for competition; new travel brochure by Stanford Alumni Assn promoting plans for adventure travel in outer space aboard private spacecraft, beginning December 2001, at cost of $98,000, noted; photos (M)

headline.main: Ambitious Entrepreneurs Planning to Send Tourists Into 'Astronaut Altitude'

results.snippet: In the Stanford Alumni Association winter travel brochure, listings for walking tours in Tuscany, cruises to the Galapagos Islands and whale watching in Mexico compete with the latest frontier in adventure travel: outer space.    ''If a journey to...
results.lead_paragraph: In the Stanford Alumni Association winter travel brochure, listings for walking tours in Tuscany, cruises to the Galapagos Islands and whale watching in Mexico compete with the latest frontier in adventure travel: outer space. ''If a journey to space has been one of your life's great dreams, this is the trip for you,'' coaxes the brochure, which waxes eloquent about the thrills of weightlessness on a quick trip aboard a private spacecraft and of making home videos of Earth's curvature at 62 miles above the planet surface. Follow-up callers are told that the trip will cost $98,000 and that the first launching is scheduled for Dec. 1, 2001, pending Federal Aviation Administration approval.

results.abstract: R W Apple Jr On the Road article on Houston, steaming, hyper-air-conditioned oil boom town that sprawls over 500 relentlessly flat square miles, and seems more green and Southern than Western; recounts rough-and-ready origins, and arrival of culture under influence of late oil heiress Dominique de Menil; Menil Collection, major private museum, is now hosting Robert Rauschenberg retrospective, along with Museum of Fine Arts and Contemporary Arts Museum; photo; map; city's architectural highlights and Rice University campus also described (M)

headline.main: A City of Surprises, Not All Big

results.snippet: This may be the fourth-largest metropolis in the United States, but it is much less well known to most Americans than the big three, Los Angeles, New York and Chicago. It is a steaming, hyper-air-conditioned, boom-bust-boom town that oozes across 500...
results.lead_paragraph: This may be the fourth-largest metropolis in the United States, but it is much less well known to most Americans than the big three, Los Angeles, New York and Chicago. It is a steaming, hyper-air-conditioned, boom-bust-boom town that oozes across 500 relentlessly flat, bayou-laced square miles, the most ethnically and racially diverse, most unionized city in all of Texas, with aching disparities between rich and poor matched in few other places in the country. It is the city that oil built. Houston was nothing much until the first gusher came in; that was Spindletop, on the Gulf coast, which blasted Houston and Texas and the whole blessed world into the era of petroleum on Jan. 10, 1901. Since then, Houston has been a city of flamboyant oilmen like Glenn McCarthy and Hugh Roy Cullen, a city of big gestures and big spenders and bigger hair, where minimalism is a dirty word and nobody would dream of dressing down.

results.abstract: Russia's Mir space station docks with cargo supply ship filled with garbage and fuel, successfully repeating maneuver that went wrong and caused near-fatal collision in 1997; ship, Progress, left Mir nearly month ago to free docking hatch for new crew to used when it arrived three weeks ago; departure of previous crew last week again opened space for ship, which had been floating on its own in space in recent weeks (M)

headline.main: Mir and Supply Ship Dock, Accomplishing Feat After Failure

results.snippet: Russia's Mir space station docked with a cargo supply ship filled with garbage and fuel today, successfully repeating a maneuver that went wrong and caused a near-fatal collision last year.    The ship, Progress, left the Mir nearly a month ago to...
results.lead_paragraph: Russia's Mir space station docked with a cargo supply ship filled with garbage and fuel today, successfully repeating a maneuver that went wrong and caused a near-fatal collision last year. The ship, Progress, left the Mir nearly a month ago to free a docking hatch for a new crew to use when it arrived three weeks ago.
